subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt,
  at an international conference on Iraq. There’s been one
  significant development already – debt relief for that war-torn country.
  But the even bigger news might be the rare contact today between U.S. officials and those from Syria.
  Sheila MacVicar is there and will have more.
 
Our national security correspondent David Martin will
  report on the diplomatic talks going on in Sharm el Sheik. And Elizabeth
  Palmer will report from the Tehran
  stock exchange, where investors are hoping the meeting could open the way to greener
  financial pastures.
 
Eighteen months before the 2008 election, 10
  Republican presidential contenders will take the stage at the Ronald Reagan
  presidential library outside of Los
    Angeles for their first debate. Sandra Hughes is
  there.
 
And Secret Service protection is being given to one
  of the Democratic Presidential candidates: Barack Obama. It is the earliest in
  a presidential campaign that protection has ever been authorized for a
  candidate.
 
Due to what Menu Foods is calling possible
  cross-contamination, the pet food maker expanded its recall today. This news
  comes as a study shows it might not be the melamine in food itself that is
  harmful, but the combination of certain chemicals. Nancy Cordes will have
  this and more.
 
Thousands of people jammed Capitol Square in Richmond, Virginia,
  today hoping to get a glimpse of Queen Elizabeth. She and her husband, Prince
  Philip, began their six-day stay in the United States today – their
  first in 16 years. Mark Phillips will report.
 
Do you have a favorite to win the Run for the Roses?
  Sharyn Alfonsi will give you a peek at some of the horses competing in this
  Saturday’s Kentucky Derby. You’ll also meet a young woman who
  paid $9,000 for a horse that will be pitted in that race against
  million-dollar thoroughbreds. 
 
And today we lost a pioneer, astronaut Wally
  Schirra. I’ll tell you about his amazing life.
 
Thanks,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
